message.content:
There is a range of data that can be made available to law enforcement agencies during investigations. This includes:

1. Personal information: Personal details like name, address, contact number, email ID, social security number or other national identification numbers can be shared with the police as part of an investigation.

2. Digital evidence: This consists of digital files such as photos and videos taken at the scene of the crime, audio recordings from witness statements, captured chats and emails in communication devices used by suspects during the commission of a crime.

3. Communications data: Metadata collected from communications service providers (CSPs), including phone call records (both incoming and outgoing), text messages exchanged between parties involved in criminal activity are also useful for law enforcement when investigating crimes.

4. Financial transactions: Bank account details; credit card transactions; tax records; cryptocurrency transaction histories which enable authorities to track the money flow connected potential illegal activities or proceeds generated from those activities could be accessed through legal means during an investigation

5. Criminal intelligence: Information on known criminals – their modus operandi, associations etc.- along with strategies employed by organized criminal groups help inform investigators while solving cases involving similar patterns/rackets

6. Surveillance footage: CCTV footage located around businesses/restaurants/public places provides valuable visual documentation that may assist in identifying people present together at crucial junctures/events—whether they are bystanders/witnesses/suspects themselves

7.Travel history & biometric data - Travel itineraries may reveal patterns related to illegal transnational activity eg- drug smuggling/human trafficking networks/routes utilized by them
